@@ -442,6 +442,52 @@ The proper way to check the active profile programmatically is to use the `getAc
 Using `@ConfigProperty("quarkus.profile")` will *not* work properly.
 ====
 
+=== Using placeholders
+
+Quarkus supports the use of placeholders in the application.properties file. This allows the replacement of the used string by the value on compilation time.
+
+The placeholder can be used by enclosing the key inside `${}`.
+
+For example having the following property:
+
+[source,properties]
+----
+remote.host=google.com
+----
+having another property defined as
+
+[source,properties]
+----
+callable.url=http://${remote.host}/
+----
+
+will result on the value of the `callable.url` property to be at compilation time

@@ -488,6 +488,30 @@ quarkus.datasource.url=jdbc:mysql://${application.server}:3306/mydatabase?useSSL
 
 It does result in one more line in this example but the value of `application.server` can be reused in other properties, diminishing the possibility of typos and providing more flexibility in properties definitions.
 
+=== Combining placeholders and environment variables
+
+Quarkus also supports the combination of both placeholders and environment variables.
+
+Let's assume you have following property defined in `application.properties`
+[source,properties]
+----
+remote.host=quarkus.io
+----
+
+You can combine environment variables and placeholders by having a property defined as follow
+[source,properties]
+----
+application.host=${HOST:remote.host}
+----
+
+This will expand the HOST environment variable and use the value of the property `remote.host` as the default value if `HOST` is not set.
